title: FCA drops Quindell probe to make way for fraud investigation
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Aug 18, 2015, 11:23 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 7 mins FCA drops Quindell probe to make way for fraud investigation By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 44 minutes ago 1.60 0.00 
The City watchdog has scrapped an investigation into the company because the Serious Fraud Office is also scutinising the firm 
The Financial Conduct Authority has dropped its probe into Quindell (Xetra: M6FA.DE - news ) to make way for a Serious Fraud Office criminal investigation into the troubled insurance outsourcer. 
The City watchdog announced in June that it would scrutinise statements that Quindell had made about its accounts in 2013 and 2014. Since then, however, the Aim-listed company has published drastic restatements of its 2013 results and, within hours of Quindell revising its numbers, the SFO announced its own investigation into “business and accounting practices” at the firm. 
On Tuesday, the FCA said that “in the light” of the SFO probe, and after consulting with the fraud investigator, it had decided to scrap its Quindell inquiry with immediate effect. Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in the Aim company rose as much as 3.9pc on the news in early morning trade. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is not unusual for the FCA to stop an investigation if it overlaps significantly with an SFO probe and there had been speculation that the City regulator might drop its probe into Quindell. It emerged earlier this month that the Financial Reporting Council had also launched its own review of the firm last year and is now examining the work of Quindell’s current and previous accountants, KPMG and RSM Tenon. 
The Aim company, which provides telematics technologies used by insurer to track drivers' habits, shocked investors a fortnight ago when it overhauled its new management team and revised its 2013 figures, revealing the business had suffered a £64m pre-tax loss instead of the £107m profit its former bosses had reported. 
Using more conservative accounting policies than had been adopted by its old management team, chairman Richard Rose also announced that Quindell had slumped to a £375m loss in 2014. 
Mr Rose replaced Quindell’s controversial founder Rob Terry as chairman of the business and has brought about sweeping changes at the company in an effort to restore investor confidence. On Monday, he announced that Indro Mukerjee had been appointed as the company’s new chief executive and that Cenkos Securities (LSE: CNKS.L - news ) had been replaced as its nominated adviser by Peel Hunt. 
Since leaving Quindell in November, Mr Terry has pursued a fund management venture called Quob Park Estate. The vehicle has built a stake in listed stockbroker Daniel Stewart and had been hoping to gain FCA clearance to lift its shareholding above 9.99pc. However, Quob Park has said that it "would not plan to gain FCA approval" for further shares purchases until all investigations in Quindell are finished, including the SFO and FRC probes (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
